turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> Hello?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi. Hi. My name is Doctor Jacob, and welcome to Babylon. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> How are you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I'm I'm I'm good. I mean I <UNIN/> I'm uh, so, I'm bad.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Your <UNIN/>, OK. Right so just before we start, is it alright if you could confirm your name for me please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, your date of birth?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Seventeen of January, nineteen eighty seven.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And your address for me, please.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, <UNSURE>sixty Hanover steps.</UNSURE> Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That's <UNSURE>good</UNSURE>. And, just to confirm that you're in a secure location and we can have a confidential conversation.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: London.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, you mentioned in our notes that you've got, um, skin problem. If you can tell me a bit more about it, please.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, <UNIN/> over the past few days I had uh, I've noticed my skin is uh, sore and red.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So where  is <UNSURE>it</UNSURE> sore and red?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, it's uh, all over my chest, my hands and arms, and especially inside of the elbows. And, uh

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> that.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> on the, on the inside of the elbow.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Elbows</UNSURE>, OK. Inside of the elbows, yeah?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Which is the, the worst area.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Alright,  <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> area. Is it very itchy?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: It's very itchy and, uh, dry, all over my body

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Itchy and dry, OK. Have you had something like this in the past?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, uh, if I haven't <UNIN/> had <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Do you think this is similar to your usual eczema, or is it worse?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I think it's, yeah, it's <UNSURE>getting</UNSURE> worse, like, the past few days. <UNSURE>Way worse</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. But you, could be like something similar. So on the skin is there any, you know any of the patches, <UNIN/> sore and you mentioned it's quite sore. Is it weeping? Is it like watery liquid coming from that area? Weeping? <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Nothing <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>. OK. Right.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: But, but, not the areas that are cracked.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. So you have cracks over there, OK. And is there any scratch marks on your, on any of the, you know, areas, any scratch marks?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I mean uh, it's very itchy if I scratch myself, but there's no scratch mark.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>No</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Is there any thickened skin? Like, <UNIN/> you know, where it's, the skin's very, um, thick, and darkened areas?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mmm, no, no, I don't think, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.  <UNSURE>Uh, righty-ho</UNSURE>. So, you've mentioned you've, got a history of eczema, so what do you do about it? <UNIN/> How do you keep it under control?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, usually I use a a a cream called <UNSURE>diprobase</UNSURE>. Uh, and in the shower I use something called <UNSURE>dermal</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Dermal</UNSURE>, alright, and have you been using them recently, or not?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes. Yes,  I, I use them.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>You </UNSURE> use them every day?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes I, there there's no change in that. I didn't change any <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Have you ever used steroids in the past, for your eczema?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I, I, I'm not sure. Uh, ah, yes, yes, <UNIN/> yes, I remember now, I <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You've used steroids before?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, but it, it's not helping. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. Also, you're still using the steroids.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I tried. I tried.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Which one are you using, the steroids? What's the name?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I'm not sure, it's uh, <UNSURE> I would have </UNSURE> <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> <UNSURE>the box is</UNSURE> not there.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>, is it the <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, <UNIN/> is it like the over-the-counter ones?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Over the counter Hydrocortisone. That, does that ring a <UNIN/> ? Yeah. So you're using the Hydrocortisone, yeah?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you using any antihistamines at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, no antihistamines. OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, fine. Otherwise, other than those rash, you're feeling well in yourself. There's no temperature, no joint pains, yeah? <UNIN/> No fever?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> But, I remember that I've tried <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> and it didn't work.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You've tried the antihistamines <UNSURE>and it</UNSURE> didn't work. OK which one did you try?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: The one over-the-counter.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, so like <UNSURE>cetirizine</UNSURE>, yeah?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, OK, that's fine. Right. OK, so from what you're describing,

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: It looks like, you know, it is quite widespread, your eczema.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah? 'Cause you're having it all over your chest and <UNIN/> hands and things like that. Um. So do you have any <UNIN/> allergies to any medication at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no allergies.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No allergies, OK. And you don't, other than eczema you don't have <UNIN/> any other medical condition.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I, I have <UNIN/> asthma, and, uh, in my family, uh, there's hypothyroidism and migraine. My mother has migraine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> Mother has migraine and, what was the other one, I didn't understand.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE><UNIN/> hypothyroidism</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> who who has hypothroidism?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: My mother.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, she has hyperthyroidism. OK. That's fine. Right here, you mentioned you have asthma. So, what medications are you using for asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um uh, you know, probably <UNSURE>neither</UNSURE>. Uh

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The <UNSURE>blue inhaler</UNSURE>? So you don't, you don't use it everyday, so you just use it on and off, yeah?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Blue inhalers. But your breathing's all OK, yeah?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, yeah, yeah. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> It's only when I have a flare. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Sure</UNSURE>. <UNIN/> So, what we need to do is, obviously, you've got <UNIN/>, as I've mentioned. So, extensive eczema.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What we'll do, we need a couple of minutes. Because to keep your a bit comfortable, we'll, you would probably need some antihistamines, which I'm going to prescribe.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Also, hydrocortisone is a baby steroid that you use for young children. You might probably need a bit more stronger one, like <UNSURE>betnovate</UNSURE>or something like that. OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So we'll try that first. So I'm going to <UNIN/> it's called the antihistamine is called Fexofenadine. And then we'll try with some Betnovate first. So it's like very small amount, like it's like one fingertip.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. This much is, is enough to cover your palms.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And your - back of your hands, yeah?  So it's very small amounts, so that if you can imagine you can cover with a very small amount the whole body.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. So use that. You, you have to use it twice a day, for the next couple of weeks.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. If, if there's no improvement, you need to get back to us. Or, if you have any kind of adverse reaction, like an allergic reaction, which is unlikely, but if it still happens you need to get in touch with us. OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> So, what we're going to do is, we're going to send off the prescription to your pharmacy. It looks like Boots on the systems, is that correct?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah? Yes, so i'll send it across to Boot's. And it will be there for <UNIN/> collecting.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: If things are getting worse in the next two weeks, call us before hand. Otherwise, wait for two weeks, take the medication and the cream.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You still need to continue on your, emollients like the dermal soap, and, as well as the, <UNSURE>diprovate</UNSURE>. Yeah, so you still need to use those, in the interim. Any questions at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. No questions. Thank you. Thank you very

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK then.</UNSURE> You take care then. Bye bye now.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Bye. Bye.
